Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Interoperability Framework for Future Internet Architectures

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Information Centric Networks (ICNs) promise to fundamentally change the way we think of communication, moving from location-specific interactions to name-based communication. Names identify anything from users and devices, to content and even virtual entities. ICN has been recognized as a key direction to architect the Future Internet, as evidenced by the efforts currently supported by the NSF's Future Internet Architecture (FIA) projects, especially Named Data Networking (NDN) and MobilityFirst. The two approaches have fundamental differences in naming (hierarchical human and machine readable names for NDN versus flat identifiers for MobilityFirst and in name resolution ('in-band' versus 'out-of-band'). Developing a way to interoperate between these different network architectures will therefore be an important area on which to focus.

The project will broadly address the interoperability of network architectures that use differing approaches for naming and name resolution. This is a fundamental and evolving issue that is likely to be of increasing and significant concern as networks evolve to become more information centric. While the NDN and MobilityFirst FIA projects are two specific approaches for information centric networking, they are symptomatic of the fundamental ways in which networks may evolve in supporting name resolution (which is needed not just for information centric environments, but also for seamless mobility, which MobilityFirst seeks to also achieve) and structuring names. Examining interoperation of architectures of different types of naming and name resolution will be of value in the long term.

One of the primary reasons for this effort is that approaches to reason about interoperability of name-based network architectures are at an early stage. This project uses a somewhat new approach to reasoning about interoperability by developing both abstractions related to specific issues in network architectures and also looking at specific examples of the two still evolving FIA architectures. The outcome of this exploratory effort will be specific abstractions that can then be used as a design pattern for interoperability between architectures. Over the last two years, the principal investigator (PI) has worked with both NDN and MobilityFirst, and is in a unique position to undertake this effort. The PI expects to find novel ways of integrating simulation and testbed experiments to evaluate scalability and performance of the interoperability architecture.

The effort will have a beneficial impact on the entire NSF FIA program as a result of the in-depth understanding of the tradeoffs being made in the different FIA Architectures. It is expected that the architectural contribution from this project will be the development of mechanisms and protocols for inter-working between the NDN and MobilityFirst architectures. This will yield long-term benefits for the evolution of the Internet to a future information-oriented architecture, as intended by the FIA program. The project will also directly support two graduate students at UC Riverside, one of America's most diverse research-intensive universities and one of only a handful of accredited research-intensive Hispanic Serving Institutions. The principal investigator will offer a new graduate level course on FIA, and disseminate his educational materials as well as his research results.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The area of Information-Centric Networks has gained considerable interest among researchers. ICN seeks to change from location-specific interactions to name-based communication. There are two main approaches as part of the Future Internet Architecture (FIA) projects - Named Data Networking (NDN) and MobilityFirst (MF) that this project has focused on. They have fundamental differences in naming (hierarchical human and machine-readable names for NDN versus flat identifiers for MobilityFirst). Another main difference is in name resolution (“in-band” for NDN versus “out-of-band” for MobilityFirst). For this EAGER project, we proposed to have a well-reasoned, careful design for interoperability between the two ICN architectures and IP, carefully identifying the proper abstractions to capture the conceptual issues regarding interoperability.  We have developed a framework for interoperability across the three network architectures (IP, NDN, and MF) for accessing and distributing content, with the content residing in their native form on nodes in their own architecture and with minimal change to clients. We have also included the capability to support publish/subscribe and to support dynamic content (e.g., the result of a search query). Our approach meets the following design goals: no architectural modification to existing domains, seamless request/response delivery for clients and a minimum amount of state maintained at gateways enabling interoperability. No new layer is introduced.

The approach leverages an object resolution service (i.e., to be able to have a server that resolves free-form search queries to ICN names) called ORICE. ORICE translates approximate, non-specific, free-form textual search queries generated by users based on keywords and other terms (just as we see in the Internet today) to return NDN, IP or MF names for content that is accessible from NDN resident end-points, return IP URLs for content that is accessible from IP end-points, or return flat identifiers for MobilityFirst. We developed a prototype of ORICE that interoperates with content available on NDN, IP, and MF and published a paper in IEEE LANMAN 2015.

We developed a formal model of our framework, which we use to investigate the correctness of our claims, justify our design choices and also provide a means for other researchers to further analyze interoperability solutions. For this purpose, we used Alloy Analyzer. These instances can be sample snapshots of a network (when some predicate is true) or counterexamples (raised when an assertion is false). The Alloy Analyzer takes a model specification written in Alloy, an expressive relation-based language, and converts it to a series of CNFs and automatically solves predicates and assertions using SAT (satisfiability) solvers. The properties we defined and verified for the object resolution service are the ability to search for a keyword, the ability to receive the content ID from the object resolution server, no conflict between different requests from the same client, no conflict between the same request from different clients and preserving the reverse path forwarding policy inside an NDN domain. For the content retrieval service, we verified reachability and ‘returnability’ of repositories and objects residing in a remote domain.

We studied the topic of hierarchical names vs. flat IDs carefully and observed that having a network layer naming framework that is agnostic to the multitude of naming schemas at the application layer provides significant scalability advantages. However, having various naming schemas at the application layer, including hierarchical naming is extremely useful and provides flexibility for accessing content or delivering information to the correct recipients. We published a paper in IEEE LANMAN 2016.

Another major achievement is our development of a framework using ICN for Disaster Management. Disaster management critically depends on timely and efficient communication. To better deal with an incident, authorities from different services (e.g., fire, police) and jurisdictions need to work together in a new dynamically created team, different from their original organizational/administrative hierarchy. We proposed CNS, leveraging the benefits of ICN to provide the essential communication for efficiently managing disasters. We first designed a namespace enabling dynamic creation and evolution of incident-related (sub-)namespaces to represent roles of first responders assigned to the disaster. This allows first responders to receive the appropriate information on a timely basis, with senders addressing the recipients based on their roles. Predefined namespace templates for disaster types minimize management overhead for establishing communication. We also find the need for a new enhanced forwarding rule to support such a recipient hierarchy. We developed a prototype demonstrating feasibility and efficiency. With the help of large-scale simulations and real-world disaster traces, we compared CNS with an IP-based solution. CNS can significantly reduce network load and latency in addition to the qualitative benefits of simplified operations, appropriate prioritization and security.

Overall, we have published 7 conference and workshop papers and 1 poster as part of this project. Several are under submission or being revised to be re-submitted.
